The BXC 9/11 Memorial Workout will be held on Monday, September 14 at the Bartlesville High School track at 4:00 p.m.

Last year, Bartlesville Cross Country (BXC) Coach Scott Vermeire, an Air Force veteran, started the BXC 9/11 Memorial Workout dedicated to those first responders that sacrificed their lives to save others and to the innocent men and women lost that day. The event will involve the Bartlesville cross country team and some Bartlesville first responders. It is also open to BXC parents and other BHS athletes to participate.

The workout consists of three parts:
1. Nine Flights of Pain- run nine flights of stadium steps (each roughly 62.5 meters), to represent all the flights of stairs first responders climbed to help save people trapped in the Tower.
2. 11 Sprints of Honor- each sprint being 37.5 meters, representing the 412 first responders who died that day.
3. 2001 Meters of Remembrance- 5 laps around the track plus one meter at the end, which is 2,977 meters, representing the number of lives lost on 9-11.

(Picture from last year by Joe Williams)

Mandy Lumbley, who has taught English in the district since 2012, has been selected to serve as an Assistant Principal at Bartlesville High School for the 2020-2021 academic year. She will be replacing Marsha Fouts, who will be moving back into a counseling role, including support for the new Bruin Virtual School’s blending learning and online opportunities.

Ms. Lumbley was named the English Language Arts Secondary Department Chair in 2018, responsible for facilitating monthly professional development and collaborating with secondary English teachers on curricular alignment. During Mandy’s tenure with Bartlesville Public Schools, she has served as a team lead, a mentor teacher assisting new and aspiring teachers, an assistant volleyball coach, and as a teacher representative on several district committees. She recently completed an administrative internship, observing and assisting Bartlesville High School administrators. Mandy earned her master’s degree in Educational Leadership and a Bachelor of Science in Education from Pittsburg State University in Pittsburg, Kansas.

On the evening of January 23, Wilson Elementary School, marked the conclusion of the first, Raising Highly Capable Kids, parent training with a graduation celebration for parents and students. Ms. Karen Salge, Wilson Elementary Counselor, organized and facilitated the 11-week parent training cadre.

Thirty BPS employees, including elementary counselors, principals, family support coordinators, teacher leaders, along with community partners attended Raising Highly Capable Kids facilitator training in early August. The training and materials were made available to all elementary sites through a grant brought to the attention of administrators by Stephen and Jana Russell.
Any BPS parents of elementary students who are interested in attending a session are encouraged to contact their site principals for specific information

Hey Rusty!

Rusty Ryan passed away Saturday afternoon at the Journey Home hospice care facility. He was loved by so many, and we will all miss his ornery antics and cinnamon candy. We all agree the world was a better place because Rusty was in it.

Rusty has been a part of the Bruin family for more than 30 years. He began in 1985 as a custodian at Wilson Elementary. He was the Classified Person of the Year in 2001. After a brief retirement, he returned as the district mail carrier where he was able to both serve and entertain the staff at every site.

Funeral services for Ronald "Rusty" Dean Ryan, 84, will be held at 2:30 p.m. on Wednesday, November 13, at First Church of the Nazarene, 3650 SE Adams Blvd in Bartlesville.

post_text: The Bruin Middle School Cross Country team, led by Coach Vermeire, hosted a commemorative 9/11 workout this week. Way to go, Bruins!
shared_text:
Central Middle School - Bartlesville, OK
September 13, 2019 at 8:52 AM ·

SHOUT OUT to Coach Vermeire, the junior high cross country team, and all those who joined them for the commemorative, and memorable, 9/11 workout this week.

Not only did the middle school teams do the following workout, but the high school teams joined as well as the middle school volleyball team, parents and coaches:

9 Flights of Pain – (roughly 62.5m each) – The bleacher stairs represent all the flights of stairs the first responders had to climb in all their gear to reach those people they could save.

11 Sprints of Honor – (37.5 meters each – total of 412 meters) – The total distance of these sprints (412m) represents the number of first responders that died that day.

2001 Meters of Remembrance – (5 Laps + 1m) This final run rounds out the total distance for the workout to 2977m. 2,977 was the total number of lives lost on 9/11.

We would like to increase workout participation for 9/11/2020; be on the lookout next year if you or your team would like to join in honoring the heroes and victims of this tragic event.
